@Tim McCoy --

Having untangled your tortured grammar, I can raise my hand and emphatically say I do not think the NSA has a secret register of "every electronic communication that begins, initiates, suggests, alludes to, offers, makes a purchase, delivers, picks up or otherwise completes a gun sale of any kind on line or employing any kind of telecommunication"

Sheesh -- the NICS database doesn't even keep very good track of what it's supposed to keep track of!

History has shown that is pretty much impossible for anything as big as an NSA secret register to be kept secret for very long, with or without a Daniel Ellsberg, an Edward Snowden or Julian Assange to spring the leak. Is anyone really foolish enough to believe that very much can be secret or private in the age of the Internet?

@Tim McCoy --

You post daily about the many causes of death other than firearms. Often, as today, you emphasize the deaths of children from accidental, preventable causes other than guns. Mainly you raise the specter of auto deaths. Or poisoning.

Why? If your posts are intended to do anything other than obfuscate the physical, psychological, social and financial damage to communities caused by gun death and injury, please enlighten us.

As you know, the US has mounted major efforts to enhance motor vehicle safety and to diminish death and injury in motor vehicle crashes, particularly those involving children. They have proven effective.

We have laws mandating safety provisions for swimming pools and spas; most housing codes include fire safety measures. We have laws requiring not only prescription drugs but also most hazardous common household substances to be packaged in child-proof containers.

But you know all that. I will hazard a guess that your alleged concern for accidental child injuries and deaths has less to do with children and more to do with concerns that gun safety regulations will lead down the slippery slope to registration and confiscation.

Your accusations of the "myopia" of the Gun Report in the face of all these children's deaths from other causes is ridiculous. If you want to read about safety in any of the areas you mention, you can find blogs about auto safety, fatal childhood cancers, rare diseases.

Even toenail fungus has its followers.

(Though many second graders have the reading and comprehension skills to hand color those words -- or would, if our public schools were not catering to the lowest common denominator, and our culture awash in contempt for the intellect)

But I digress: The sign is the work of acclaimed Pennsylvania painter and performance artist Vanessa German, who began painting signs of love and hope and peace on the front porch of her home in her violent Pittsburgh neighborhood about a year ago. Another person has already referred to her in today's blog.

I'm not amazed, but rather sorrowful at the cynicism displayed by the gun advocates here re: this poster and the child holding it on Ms. German's front porch. Would you rather teach children to hate or to love? To make peace or to make war?

HagbardCeline: And I also find it hard to believe that Doc Rivers didn't know he was going to work for a racist when he signed that huge contract to coach for the racist. With all the history of prior racist activity Sterling was involved with, Doc Rivers comes off as a hypocrite and should keep quiet about this situation. And the piling on comes at an opportunistic moment when black ownership of an NBA team in a primo market is a real possibility. I'll be that was part of the deal to ensure that this year's playoffs go on: Sterling loses his team (all Sterlings lose their team apparently), and the NBA guaranties black ownership of the Clippers. That's why Magic Johnson keeps piling on as well. I suggest that Mrs Sterling get in touch with Al Davis' legal team if she wants any shot at retaining ownership. I'm not in any way excusing Sterling's comments. But I think a more considered approach would be to treat him like a deluded old man losing her mind and pity him. Do what the NFL did to Eddie D - take control of the team from him. I don't know if it's right to take the team from his estranged wife. You people throw around the term "racist" as if you know what it means.  Black or white, positive or negative, all or nothing--what could be simpler, what could make me look better!   Try looking in the mirror for a few minutes; let he who is without sin cast the first stone.

A very well thought out comment. Only two additional thoughts/conments:
1. About knowledge of Donald's prejudices: they have been married 50 years, not the 20 mentioned; and
2. Mrs. Sterling alleges that she possesses business acumen: in what business has she been involved. More specifically, what was her involvement in the real estate business that was fined for racial discrimination?

It's a nice gambit to pull the gender card when backed into a corner, but it's a weak lunge that should be sufficiently parried by the league.

I find it hard-- if not impossible-- to believe that the significant other of a racist doesn't know he's a racist. Since this is America, race is something almost always at the surface of things, or at least incessantly bubbling just below the surface. The unmitigated and unflinching bigotry expressed by her husband demonstrates the unrestrained linguistic trappings of the most privileged among us-- the heterosexual white male.

But whether she knew or didn't know really shouldn't be the issue. The issue should be a broader understanding of your place in the history of this country's race relations, and whether you wish to be on the right side or the wrong side of history.

The wrong way is to say, Hey, I had no idea, I didn't know anything about a man I was married to for 20 years-- 20 years!-- and instead I'll blame it on dementia and other things.

The right way is to say, My husband is the last thing this league needs, and even though I may not share my husband's views, I understand that it's best for me to sell the team to people clearly removed from racist impulses. It hurts me to do so, but what's best for the team and for the country, both for the present and the future, is to hand the team over to someone, or some group, that is clearly for black people, rather than against them.

The decision is up to her.

What specious reading, are you referring to Dr. L?

The one which claims the Second Amendment, alone out of all the Bill of Rights, is about the rights of the Federal Government? The one which claims 2A is a garbled mess, while the rest of the Constitution is not? The one which claims the entire Constitution is fatally flawed because slavery was allowed in the original version? Which incidentally did not include the Bill of Rights. Or the one left over from the collectivist era (1917-1991) which claims any enumerated right within the Bill of Rights is a collective right if a person with collectivist political beliefs says so?

Obviously, Richard DeBacher views the 2nd Amendment as espousing a collective, and not individual right, and considers the individualist interpretation of the post collectivist era (1917-1991) Supreme Court as "outrageous".

In the context of the English common law before the Bill of Rights was adopted, Mr. DeBacher ignores the almost universal individual ownership of private firearms, and certain limitations on individual free speech imposed by the British Crown.

If it was necessary to begin the Bill of Rights with the 1st Amendment due to the limitations on free expression that existed previously, why would it be necessary to make the next one about private gun ownership as an addendum to the organization of Federal Militias? Both Federal Militia and private gun ownership existed before the Bill of Rights.

To the collectivist mind the Bill of Rights exists, at least in part, to make the citizen's support of state power more efficient, and nothing else.
No surprise there.

Deb my right to keep and bear arms does not come from my membership in the militia. I have a natural right to self-defense. I have a common law right to self-defense. I have a Constitutional right to self-defense since the Heller case. That means that not only can I keep and bear arms, I can use those arms to defend my life. It's not a right to hunt or to shoot paper targets, it is a legal, natural and civil right to use my gun to take the life of a person who would take mine.

There is nothing in the second amendment as it stands now to bar Congress from legislating the legal definition of "well regulated militia", and specifying its regulations and the penalties for violating them.

It should also be added that since the charges against the Sterlings were civil they had the legal right to settle with the plaintives rather than fight it in court.  They did not admit guilt.  Kobe Bryant paid his accuser not to testify in a criminal case. Michael Jackson did the same thing. That is not legal.
I assume you are comparing her husband's remarks to genocide?  Goodwin's Law my friend.

I also look the kids in the eye if they're there and tell them that they are lucky to have their parents and THEY ARE THE BOSS and to never touch what they are looking at in my hand without their permission. I also tell the parents and kids that when my kids were small I had a firm rule that if they were at a friends' house and the friend presented what he said was a toy gun they were forbidden to touch or play with it until the kid's parent confirmed it was a toy. If the friend didn't go for that my kids were instructed to immediately call home, and wait outside for me or my wife.

You people who think I and other legal gun sellers only care about money don't know anything about the retail gun business. It's weird how ignorant you are in your stereotypes. Do you stereotype other people the same way?
